Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: SHINE: Data-constrained Simulations of Coronal Mass Ejection Initiation and Propagation
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project addresses coronal mass ejections (CMEs) which are violent expulsions of plasma from the Sun that contribute to space weather. It is vital to understand how these eruptions happen and how they propagate towards Earth in order to accurately predict their behavior. The current fleet of solar and space observatories provides unprecedented temporal and spatial coverage of the surface magnetic field, extreme ultraviolet (EUV) and X-ray coronal structures. In this study, data-constrained simulations of CME initiation and propagation will be performed starting from realistic initial conditions for the magnetic field and plasma of an active region that contains a flux rope on the verge of eruption. These simulations will provide a unique opportunity to investigate the processes behind the eruption and early development of CMEs.
The project has the following science objectives: 1) Develop models of CME initiation that are highly constrained by observations in order to study the early development phases of CMEs; 2) Constrain CME properties near the Sun (kinetics, morphology, shock and compression region parameters) based on the flux rope properties and the ambient coronal field, and 3) Reproduce the observed three-part and two-front structure of CMEs and their in situ properties using data-constrained magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) simulations.
Data-constrained non-linear force-free field (NLFFF) models of observed erupting active regions will be used as initial conditions to the Space Weather Modeling Framework (SWMF) global MHD code. The initial conditions on the active region and flux rope plasma will also be constrained by data using recently developed analysis techniques. These tools will be used to propagate more realistic CMEs to 1AU. The properties of the simulated CMEs (direction, velocity, acceleration, morphology, and shock-driving capability) will be compared with all available observations (coronal EUV and X-ray, white-light and in situ data).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overaching goal of this project is to improve our understanding about the initiation and propagation of coronal mass ejections (CMEs). CMEs are originated on the Sun but propagate into the interplanetary space. Some of these CMEs will impact the Earth, causing severe disturbances in our space environment, the so-called space weather. It is well known that space weather may have a host of adverse effects on human technological systems that are critical to human activities, including satellite operation, communication, navitgaion and space exploration. This project makes use of advanced three-dimensional magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) numerical simulation and unprecedented observations from a suite of spacecraft, to achieve a major advancement in our understaninding of CMEs.  The specific objectives are (1) develop models of CME initiation that are highly constrained by observational data, (2) constrain CME properties near the Sun from observations, and (3) reproduce the observed three-part and two-front sructure of CMEs and their in-situ properties. This is a collaborative effort involving George Mason University, Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, University of Michigan and University of New Hampshire.   

 

We have made a detailed numerical and observational study of the 2010 April 8 CME. We have found excellent consistency between simulations and observations, i.e., the imaging and timing in coronal EUV images and white light coronagraph images are nearly the same as the ones generated from simulations. We have carried out a comprehensive study of the 2012 July 12 event. The study successfully captures the properties of the full evolution of the event from the Sun to the Earth, including the pre-eruption activity, initiation, acceleration in the corona, propagation near the Sun, propagation in the interplanetary space and the features at 1 AU. We have carried out and finisheda statistical study of all Earth-affecting CME events during solar cycle 24. A total of 70 Earth-affecting CME events from 2007 to 2015 are identified. Their major properties near the Sun and at 1 AU are investigated. We carefully studied one eruption from NOAA Active Region 11429 on March 10, 2012, in order to understand the physics process that leads to the formation of magnetic flux rope and its eventual eruption. We concluded that the event is caused by a successive eruption of two magnetic flux ropes that are formed in a double-deck configuration prior to the eruption.  We also made a study of the origin of one interplanetary CME (ICME) whose source region appears to the “stealthy”, i.e., that is no apparant solar CME counterpart (halo or partial halo CMEs) as seen from SOHO spacecraft at the L1 point along the Sun-Earth line. The lack of solar signatures poses a challenge for space weather prediction. We use STEREO data to explore the possible source events and source regions on the Sun, and we are successful in finding the sources. 

 

The implementation of this project has made significant process in our understanding of CMEs. On the broad impact, the project helps promote the integration between reseach and teaching. The reserch activity is assimilated into the teaching activity at George Mason University. Several PHD studente are participated in the project, and one has already obtained his PHD through the study of Sun-Earth connection. The results of this project have been dissimated to the wide  community through many scientific conferences, several peer-reviewed journal acticles and one edited book. This project strengthens the infrastructure of Space Weather Lab at GMU. It helps the lab to create a data center that holds a large amount of data from multiple spacecraft, including SDO, STEREO, SOHO, ACE, WIND and other instruments. This data center is an invaluable resource for training students and future research.
